channel.title: (508) server problem
channel.description:
enviromental variables chapter four: enviromental variables.
okay now you have to set your enviromental variables go to my computer> system properties> advanced tab> enviromental variables now try and find a thing called 'classpath' if you don't have make one and edite it and put this in CODE CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_**\bin;%CLASSPATH%; replace the ** with your jdk version. now find a thing named 'path' and if you don't have make one and name it PATH and put this in CODE C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_**\bin; once again replace the ** with your jdk version.
Im not sure how to this can someone explain to me how please thanks =)
-joescape team

item.title: (508) server problem
item.dc:creator: @King_Lingerz King Lingerz
item.description:
@King_Lingerz wrote:

… If you have jdk 11 then you would put CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;%CLASSPATH%;

Read full topic

item.title: (508) server problem
item.dc:creator: @lordbroseph lordbroseph
item.description:
@lordbroseph wrote:

enviromental variables
chapter four: enviromental variables.

okay now you have to set your enviromental variables go to my computer> system properties> advanced tab> enviromental variables now try and find a thing called ‘classpath’ if you don’t have make one and edite it and put this in
CODE
CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_\bin;%CLASSPATH%;
replace the ** with your jdk version. now find a thing named ‘path’ and if you don’t have make one and name it PATH and put this in
CODE
C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_\bin;
once again replace the ** with your jdk version.

Im not sure how to this can someone explain to me how please thanks =)

-joescape team

Read full topic
